fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.hioa.models

Class AtomicHIOA

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.models.Model
      • fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.models.AtomicModel
        • fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.hioa.models.AtomicHIOA
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    VariableDefinitionsAndSharingI, VariableInitialisationI, AtomicModelI, EventsExchangingI, ModelI, java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AbstractPlottingHIOA, BatterySensorModel, HIOA_Consumer, HIOA_Generator, HIOA_Multiplier, PortableComputerStateModel, WiFiBandwidthModel, WiFiBandwidthSensorModel

    public abstract class AtomicHIOA
extends AtomicModel
    The abstract class AtomicHIOA implements the base level hybrid input/output automata, having imported, internal and exported variables as well as events which implementation is based on and inherited from DEVS atomic models.

    Description

    See the package fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.hioa for more information about Hybrid Input/Output Automata and their overall implementation as simulation models.

    Concrete atomic HIOA are defined as by the Java class (subclasses of AtomicHIOA) by their imported, internal and exported variables as well as their trajectories which are expressed by equations within the simulation protocol methods like userDefinedInternalTransition. Variables are declared as fields in user-defined models and indicated by annotations put on these fields (@see fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.hioa.annotations). Thus, the required information to define the variables of the HIOA is gathered at run time from these annotations: @ImportedVariable, @ExportedVariable and @InternalVariable put by the user on the declared fields.

    For example, an exported variable x of type double is declared as follows: 

          @ExportedVariable(type = Double.class)
      protected final Value<Double> x = new Value<Double>(this);

    The type defined in the annotation is the one used as the generic parameter of the class Value<T>. Notice that exported variables are declared as final, hence the placeholder for its values, instance of Value<Double>, will remain the same throughout the simulation and will be shared with the other atomic HIOA models that import the variable.

    An internal variable y of type double is declared as follows: 

          @InternalVariable(type = Double.class)
      protected final Value<Double> y = new Value<Double>(this);

    For internal variables, the placeholder is used for the sake of homogeneity in the treatment of model variables, as they can't be shared with other models but rather hidden in the declaring one.

    An imported variable z of type double is declared as in the following: 

          @ImportedVariable(type = Double.class)
      protected Value<Double> z;

    An imported variable is not final nor initialised because they will be linked to the exported one during the HIOA simulation models composition process.

    Exported and internal variables can also be initialised in the model class constructor but no later for the composition of models to work properly.

    Glass-box Invariants

    TODO: check declared variables with annotations 
     invariant       importedVariables != null
 invariant       exportedVariables != null
 invariant       internalVariables != null
 invariant       variables2values != null
 invariant       variables2values.isEmpty() || Stream.of(exportedVariables).allMatch(v -> variables2values.containsKey(v) && variables2values.get(v) != null)
 invariant       variables2values.isEmpty() || Stream.of(internalVariables).allMatch(v -> variables2values.containsKey(v) && variables2values.get(v) != null)

    Black-box Invariants

    TODO: check imported/exported variables with annotations 
     invariant       true        // no more invariant

    Created on : 2018-06-28

    Author:
    Jacques Malenfant

    • Constructor Detail

      • AtomicHIOA

        public AtomicHIOA(java.lang.String uri,
                  java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit simulatedTimeUnit,
                  AtomicSimulatorI simulationEngine)
        create an atomic hybrid input/output model with the given URI (if null, one will be generated) and to be run by the given simulator (or by the one of an ancestor coupled model if null) using the given time unit for its clock.

        Contract

         pre     uri == null || !uri.isEmpty()
 pre     simulatedTimeUnit != null
 pre     simulationEngine == null || !simulationEngine.isModelSet()
 pre     simulationEngine == null || simulationEngine instanceof AtomicEngine
 post    !isDebugModeOn()
 post    getURI() != null && !getURI().isEmpty()
 post    uri == null || getURI().equals(uri)
 post    getSimulatedTimeUnit().equals(simulatedTimeUnit)
 post    getSimulationEngine().equals(simulationEngine)
        Parameters:
        uri - unique identifier of the model.
        simulatedTimeUnit - time unit used for the simulation clock.
        simulationEngine - simulation engine enacting the model.
